posts.cooked:
I know Signal has disappearing message timer feature where we can set a time the message deletes after its read, but I would like the feature where the message can delete after a period of time even if it‚Äôs not read, I think this article says Signal and Whatsapp has the feature but both don‚Äôt, looks like Telegram just introduced it

image1083√ó502 136 KB

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: I‚Äôve turned this into a new feature request topic because you are basically asking for something similar to view once media messages but for text messages. Note thst view once medua messages always get deleted after I think it was 21 days even if they haven‚Äôt been viewed.
I think op is asking about message trimming and there already are multiple feature requests about a better message trimming (like on a per chat basis or availability on ios)
It‚Äôs a request for disappearing messages that disappear based on sent time rather than read time.

Isn‚Äôt that message trimming?
Chats are deleted after a given time (on the sender side)

No, message trimming is local. Disappearing messages are for everyone. The quote in the image says ‚Äúmessage are automatically erased for all participants either 24 hours or seven days after sending‚Äù, so that makes it closer to disappearing messages, or at the very least, message trimming that is enforced for everyone.

Unless the quote is unclear and actually means messages from all participants are deleted. Does someone know more details about the Telegram feature?
Is there a current message trimming function that deletes only for the person setting it?

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
View once media messages already have this functionality, even if they don‚Äôt get open an unmodified Signal app will delete such message after a set number of days. What the original poster wants is a way to set that same functionality for text messages and for media which are not view-once.

But isn‚Äôt this just the same as the existing ‚Äúdisappearing messages‚Äù? The name signal chose for that is a bit vague but they are actually just expiring messages. A time you set for all messages in the conversation and which gets set for all participants of the conversation. So I think that already completely fits the use case, the feature already exists. Signal already has this.
It‚Äôs not the same because OP wants it based on sent time, not read time. Which like you mentioned View Once Media already does (but not for the same reason).

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: disappearing mesages are also based on sent time

Not exactly, if you send me a message with a 1 hour limit, I can choose to initially look at it 2 hours from now. The timer starts after I read/open/view it.

It‚Äôs only based on sent time for the sender.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
So maybe a good solution would be to add a maximum limit to that, for example the message will be deleted 1 week after it was read, or otherwise 3 weeks after it was sent. (which also means that if you read the message 20 days after it was send you still have it for a week and thus is gets deleted after 3 weeks and 6 days)

Would that be a good solution?

posts.name: T W
posts.cooked: I think security should come first, in the example above the message should be deleted after no more than 3 week, no matter when the recipient views it (and one week after having been viewed).

posts.name: T W
posts.cooked:
This thread seems to have gone quiet.

In activist circles the fact that messages don‚Äôt necessarily disappear can cause a massive security threat.

It only takes one device (for instance one from someone who‚Äôs burned out and has taken a step back for a while, or an old devices that hasn‚Äôt been removed from all chats) to be found and seized for a complete chat history to be leaked out (potentially leading to conspiracy charges and years in prison for someone). It is really important that messages actually disappear, no matter if people read them or not.

tw58689khgbnlk:

This thread seems to have gone quiet.

If a feature request isn‚Äôt popular, controversial, or in development, there won‚Äôt be any regular activity until it‚Äôs in development.

tw58689khgbnlk:

It only takes one device (for instance one from someone who‚Äôs burned out and has taken a step back for a while, or an old devices that hasn‚Äôt been removed from all chats)‚Ä¶

There are many other valid vectors that could maintain messages including local backups on both Android and Desktop. The Disappearing messages feature should not be relied on for privacy.

yes. and disappearing messages should have some kind of warning that it is not dependent on signal servers, they depend on end device‚Äôs software.

maybe they should be called ‚Äúhalf-disappearing‚Äù or ‚Äútemporary‚Äù.
